DataElement.preferredDefinition: Stage of disease based on the metastases present (M stage).

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Stage of disease based on the metastases present (M stage).

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts, and its etiology, pathology, and prognosis may be known or unknown.

Concepts.definition: Any abnormal condition of the body or mind that causes discomfort, dysfunction, or distress to the person affected or those in contact with the person. The term is often used broadly to include injuries, disabilities, syndromes, symptoms, deviant behaviors, and atypical variations of structure and function.

Property.preferredDefinition: Cancer that has spread from the organ in which it first appeared to another organ. For example, breast cancer cells may spread (metastasize) to the lungs and cause the growth of a new tumor. When this happens, the disease is called metastatic breast cancer.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.

Concepts.definition: The spread or migration of cancer cells from one part of the body (the organ in which it first appeared) to another. The secondary tumor contains cells that are like those in the original (primary) tumor.
The extent of a cancer in the body.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ValueDomain.preferredName: American Joint Committee on Cancer Metastasis Stage Code
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications._Cancer that has spread from the organ in which it first appeared to another organ. For example, breast cancer cells may spread (metastasize) to the lungs and cause the growth of a new tumor. When this happens, the disease is called metastatic breast cancer._The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body._A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A distant metastasis TNM finding indicating that there is no evidence of distant metastasis clinically or by radiologic studies, but there are small numbers of cells detected by special studies in the blood and bone marrow, or there is tiny metastasis (no larger than 0.2 mm) detected in nonregional lymph nodes.

Concepts.definition: A distant metastasis TNM finding indicating that there is no evidence of distant metastasis clinically or by radiologic studies, but there are small numbers of cells detected by special studies in the blood and bone marrow, or there is tiny metastasis (no larger than 0.2 mm) detected in nonregional lymph nodes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A distant metastasis TNM finding indicating that there is no evidence of distant metastasis.

Concepts.definition: A distant metastasis TNM finding indicating that there is no evidence of distant metastasis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A clinical and/or pathologic distant metastasis TNM finding indicating the spread of cancer to distant anatomic sites.

Concepts.definition: A clinical and/or pathologic distant metastasis TNM finding indicating the spread of cancer to distant anatomic sites.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A TNM finding indicating the spread of cancer to distant anatomic sites.  The definition of M1a TNM finding depends on the specific type of cancer that it refers to; for example, for colorectal cancer it refers to metastasis confined to one organ or site (e.g., liver, lung, ovary, nonregional node); for prostate cancer it refers to metastasis to non-regional lymph node(s); for bone cancer it refers to metastasis to the lung.

Concepts.definition: A TNM finding indicating the spread of cancer to distant anatomic sites.  The definition of M1a TNM finding depends on the specific type of cancer that it refers to; for example, for colorectal cancer it refers to metastasis confined to one organ or site (e.g., liver, lung, ovary, nonregional node); for prostate cancer it refers to metastasis to non-regional lymph node(s); for bone cancer it refers to metastasis to the lung.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A TNM finding indicating the spread of cancer to distant anatomic sites.  The definition of M1b TNM finding depends on the specific type of cancer that it refers to; for example, for colorectal cancer it refers to metastases in more than one organ/site or the peritoneum; for prostate cancer it refers to metastasis to bone(s); for bone cancer it refers to metastasis to distant sites other than lung.

Concepts.definition: A TNM finding indicating the spread of cancer to distant anatomic sites.  The definition of M1b TNM finding depends on the specific type of cancer that it refers to; for example, for colorectal cancer it refers to metastases in more than one organ/site or the peritoneum; for prostate cancer it refers to metastasis to bone(s); for bone cancer it refers to metastasis to distant sites other than lung.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A TNM finding indicating the spread of cancer to distant anatomic sites.  The definition of M1c TNM finding depends on the specific type of cancer that it refers to; for example, for prostate cancer it refers to metastasis to anatomic site(s) other than bone, with or without bone disease; for retinoblastoma it refers to central nervous system metastasis; for melanoma of the uvea it refers to distant metastasis, with the largest diameter of the largest metastasis measuring 8.0 cm or more.

Concepts.definition: A TNM finding indicating the spread of cancer to distant anatomic sites.  The definition of M1c TNM finding depends on the specific type of cancer that it refers to; for example, for prostate cancer it refers to metastasis to anatomic site(s) other than bone, with or without bone disease; for retinoblastoma it refers to central nervous system metastasis; for melanoma of the uvea it refers to distant metastasis, with the largest diameter of the largest metastasis measuring 8.0 cm or more.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A distant metastasis TNM finding indicating that the status of distant metastasis cannot be assessed.

Concepts.definition: A distant metastasis TNM finding indicating that the status of distant metastasis cannot be assessed.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: American Joint Committee on Cancer Metastasis Stage Code
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.:Cancer that has spread from the organ in which it first appeared to another organ. For example, breast cancer cells may spread (metastasize) to the lungs and cause the growth of a new tumor. When this happens, the disease is called metastatic breast cancer.:The extent of a cancer within the body, especially whether the disease has spread from the original site to other parts of the body.:A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.definition: A group formed for the purpose of developing a system of clinical staging for cancer that is acceptable to the American medical profession and is compatible with other accepted classifications.

The spread or migration of cancer cells from one part of the body (the organ in which it first appeared) to another. The secondary tumor contains cells that are like those in the original (primary) tumor.
The extent of a cancer in the body.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

ValueDomain.origin: AJCC Based:Staging Criteria Based on American Joint Committee on Cancer System
ValueDomain.changeDescription: Versioned to correct data type and max length errors. 6/5/17 mc

DataElement.origin: AMC CRF:AIDS Malignancy Consortium Case Report Form
